## Section 1: Unit 1

### Task 1: Collect real-world categorical and numerical dataset & visualize distributions
``{r}
# Load dataset (replace with your CSV)
df <- read.csv("your_dataset.csv")
head(df)

# Identify numerical and categorical columns
num_cols <- names(df)[sapply(df, is.numeric)]
cat_cols <- names(df)[sapply(df, is.factor) | sapply(df, is.character)]

print(paste("Numerical columns:", paste(num_cols, collapse=", ")))
print(paste("Categorical columns:", paste(cat_cols, collapse=", ")))

# Numerical distribution
for(col in num_cols){
  ggplot(df, aes_string(col)) + 
    geom_histogram(bins=30, fill="skyblue", color="black") +
    ggtitle(paste("Distribution of", col)) +
    theme_minimal() -> p
  print(p)
}

# Categorical distribution
for(col in cat_cols){
  ggplot(df, aes_string(col)) +
    geom_bar(fill="orange") +
    ggtitle(paste("Distribution of", col)) +
    theme_minimal() -> p
  print(p)
}
``

### Task 2: Compare mean and median for skewed datasets
``{r}
for(col in num_cols){
  mean_val <- mean(df[[col]], na.rm=TRUE)
  median_val <- median(df[[col]], na.rm=TRUE)
  cat(paste(col, ": Mean =", round(mean_val,2), ", Median =", round(median_val,2), "\n"))
}
# Comment: For skewed distributions, median is preferred as it is robust against outliers.
``

### Task 3: Mini-report identifying best sampling strategy for a campus survey
- **Simple Random Sampling:** Equal chance for each student.  
- **Stratified Sampling:** Proportional representation by department, year, or gender.  
- **Cluster Sampling:** Surveying full classes or batches.  
- **Recommended:** Stratified sampling ensures fair representation across groups.

## Unit 2

### Task 1: Compute Binomial probabilities for product defect rate scenarios
``{r}
# Example: 10 products, 10% defect, probability of 2 defective
n <- 10
p <- 0.1
k <- 2
prob <- dbinom(k, size=n, prob=p)
prob
``

### Task 2: Solve Z-score problems
``{r}
x <- 85
mu <- 80
sigma <- 5
z <- (x - mu)/sigma
z
``

### Task 3: Normal Approximation to Binomial
``{r}
mu_norm <- n * p
sigma_norm <- sqrt(n * p * (1 - p))
prob_norm <- dnorm(k, mean=mu_norm, sd=sigma_norm)
prob_norm
``

``{r}

### Task 3: Conduct one-way ANOVA on three groups
``{r}
group <- factor(rep(1:3, each=3))
value <- c(10,12,11,14,15,16,13,14,15)
aov_res <- aov(value ~ group)
summary(aov_res)
``

### Task 4: Manual Binomial probability function

binomial_prob <- function(n, k, p) {
choose(n, k) * (p^k) * ((1 - p)^(n - k))
}
binomial_prob(10, 2, 0.1)
